title: The Very Hungry Caterpillar
author: Eric Carle
audience: a caterpillar eats his way through a week’s worth of food before making his glorious transformation into a butterfly. With colorful artwork of tissue paper and paint

title: A Wrinkle in Time
author: Madeleine L’Engle
audience: likely thanks to Disney’s recent movie adaptation

title: Harold and the Purple Crayon
author: Crockett Johnson
plot: Imagine if you could create a whole world just with one crayon. That’s what happens to Harold
audience: and his story has been sparking children’s imaginations since 1955. Harold is also a great problem-solver: For example

title: Where the Wild Things Are
author: Maurice Sendak
plot: Ranking at number one on lists of best children’s books compiled by Scholastic

title: Madeline
author: Ludwig Bemelmans
plot: In this charming story the title heroine explores Paris with her classmates
audience: then needs her appendix out! She’s the smallest in her class

title: The Tale of Peter Rabbit
author: Beatrix Potter
plot: Beatrix Potter’s classic children’s book with lovely illustrations make this little rabbit a mainstay of children’s literature over a hundred years later. In the first of many tales
audience: mischievous Peter runs into danger when he disobeys his mother and ventures into the neighbor’s garden. A story about consequences

title: Charlotte’s Web
author: E. B. White
plot: Number one on the National Education Association‘s list of the best children’s books
audience: this 1952 classic tells a tale of friendship featuring a spider named Charlotte
